block.p: Armani Retrospective Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue (89th Street); (212) 423-3500.

''Giorgio Armani,'' an exhibition of 400 dresses, jackets, suits and gowns, including some that actors wore to the Academy Awards, will be on display along with drawings, photographs and videos depicting the work of Mr. Armani over the last 25 years. Open Sunday through Wednesday, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, to 8. Admission is $12; those 65 and older and students, $8; children under 12, no charge.

Downtown Tour United Cerebral Palsy of New York City; (212) 683-6700, ext. 217.

A self-guided tour of seven homes, including a renovated 120-foot loft in the Flatiron district, a prewar apartment overlooking Gramercy Park and a duplex apartment on the roof of a 1907 bank building on West 14th Street, will take place on Tuesday, 12:30 to 4:30 p.m. Tickets, $85, in advance only.
A Day of Quilts Museum of American Folk Art, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street; (212) 595-9533.
An afternoon of demonstrations and displays by six quilt guilds from the New York area will take place on Saturday from noon to 4 p.m.

At 11 a.m., Lee Kogan, the director of the Folk Art Institute at the museum, will offer a gallery tour to highlight quilts in the exhibition of folk art donated to the museum by Cyril I. Nelson. No charge.
Design Talks Swayduck Auditorium, New York University, 65 Fifth Avenue (13th Street); (212) 229-5885.

A series of talks by designers sponsored by Parsons School of Design continues tonight at 6:30 with Michael Graves, the architect and designer. Other speakers include Raymond Waites, a product designer, on Nov. 2, and two lighting-product designers: Martha Davis, Nov. 16, and Harry Allen, Nov. 30. No charge.
Plazas and New Projects Urban Center Galleries of the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.

''The Long View,'' mounted in collaboration with the Museum of Modern Art, is a series of short exhibitions of works by young architectural firms that will be on display through Dec. 9. The projects include a look at Arnhem Central, a complex of housing, shops and transportation in the Netherlands (tomorrow through Oct. 28) and designs for the Museum of Modern Art's space in Long Island City (the former Swingline stapler factory), which will be open during the museum's renovation from 2002 through 2005 (Nov. 2 through 11). A second exhibition at the society, ''World's Most Expensive Public Space,'' includes drawings, maps, photographs and models examining 300 of New York's 503 public plazas, pocket parks and atriums. It runs through Nov. 18.
Open Monday through Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. (closed Thursday). No charge.
Open House at Nine Lofts 200 Fifth Avenue (near 23rd Street); (212) 431-2440.

On Sunday, from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., nine lofts in the Flatiron district and Chelsea will be open for a self-guided tour. One loft has an outdoor garden off the master bedroom, and another, overlooking Madison Square Park, has a marble and granite kitchen and cherrywood floors. Tickets, to benefit the 23rd Street Partnership, $45.
Art and Antiques Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212) 642-8572.
An antiques show and sale by 74 dealers opens tonight with a benefit party for the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Tickets start at $200.

There will also be an exhibition of 16 clocks from a group of Cartier clocks known as the mystery clocks, which feature hidden mechanisms and intricate designs. The show will be open tomorrow through Wednesday, from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. (Sunday, to 6), and on Oct. 26, till 7. Admission is $15.
Brownstones on Parade Boys High School, 832 Marcy Avenue near Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn; (718) 574-1979 or (718) 919-4509.

On Saturday, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., seven brownstones in Bedford-Stuyvesant will be open for a self-guided tour, including one decorated with stained glass and an 1895 Italianate house with the original wainscotting and fretwork. Crafts and antiques will be sold at the school. Tickets, to benefit the McDonald and Glee Memorial College Scholarship Fund, $15.
Worldwide Quilts New England Quilt Museum, 18 Shattuck Street, Lowell, Mass.; (978) 452-4207.

An exhibition of 30 quilts from around the world, including France, Canada, Sweden, Britain, Germany, New Zealand, Japan and the United States, starts today and runs through Jan. 6. Open Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission is $4; $3 for students and those 60 and older.
Garden Festival Rutgers Gardens at Rutgers University, U.S. Route 1 and Ryders Lane, New Brunswick, off New Jersey Turnpike Exit 9; (732) 932-8451.

Plants, shrubs, perennials, trees and dried flowers will be for sale at a garden festival on Saturday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. At 11, there will be a talk on the 10 most common gardening mistakes, and at 1, a tour of the fall foliage in the gardens and activities for children. No charge for admission.
